awd_titl_txt: Synthetic Manganese Oxides for Oxidative and Catalytic Removal of Contaminants of Emerging Concern
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program of the Division of Chemistry. Professors Huichun Zhang and Daniel Lacks of Case Western Reserve University and their students study the reactions of manganese oxide (MnOx) with emerging contaminants (ECs). There is a large variety of emerging contaminants - compounds that are increasing in our streams, rivers, lakes and oceans due to human inputs into wastewater streams.  Contaminants of emerging concern include pharmaceutical and personal care products, fire retardants, and pesticides.  Research is needed to determine if these compounds are harmful to human, animal and/or plant life. Conventional water treatment processes were not designed to remove ECs and their removal efficiencies are often insufficient. Among advanced treatment technologies, the use of MnOx is promising because these compounds are natural oxidants. Numerous synthetic MnOx are highly useful in applications such as energy production and chemical synthesis. Only a small subset of naturally abundant MnOx compounds have been examined for their reactivity in breaking down ECs. This project examines the reactivity of a variety of synthetic MnOx compounds in removing ECs. The results of this research may enable more cost-effective water treatment technologies targeting ECs removal at contaminated sites. The research efforts are coupled with an educational and outreach plan designed to involve underrepresented graduate, undergraduate, and high school students in research. Project findings are integrated into the undergraduate and graduate curriculum, and broadly disseminated to communities with diverse backgrounds, including professionals as well as the general public.  This research has important implications for safe-guarding human, animal and plant life and health.

This research employs a multi-faceted approach combining experimental and computational tools to investigate oxidation of ECs either directly by MnOx or catalytically using permanganate with MnOx. A range of MnOx are first synthesized to have different structures, Mn oxidation states, porosity, and dopants. Then, a variety of MnOx properties are characterized experimentally, including morphological, structural, surface, electrochemical, compositional, and thermodynamic properties.  Some of these compounds are designed theoretically. Based on the observed reactivity of MnOx as either an oxidant or a catalyst, quantitative structure-activity relationships are developed as a function of MnOx properties. Finally, MnOx reaction mechanisms are elucidated using multipronged approaches. These include examining the role of Mn(III) species, lattice oxygen, Mn-O bond, and Lewis acid sites, and conducting kinetic modeling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This research delves into how synthetic manganese oxides (MnOx) can effectively eliminate emerging contaminants from water, wastewater, and polluted sites through oxidative and catalytic reactions. With numerous emerging contaminants like pharmaceuticals, personal care products, endocrine disruptors, fire retardants, and pesticides continuously entering the environment, MnOx, naturally occurring in various settings like ocean floors, soils, sediments, rock dendrites, desert varnishes, and freshwater bodies, play a crucial role as natural oxidants. While existing studies mainly focus on the kinetics and mechanisms of contaminant oxidation, little is known about how different MnOx structures and physicochemical properties impact their reactivity. Previous research has concentrated on degrading contaminants using a limited number of naturally abundant MnOx, overlooking over 30 highly reactive synthetic MnOx with applications in energy production, oxidative chemical reactions, and chemical synthesis. This study aims to systematically explore the reactivity of a diverse range of synthetic MnOx in breaking down various emerging contaminants.

Intellectual Merit

This groundbreaking study is the first to comprehensively explore how a large number of MnOx act as both direct oxidants and catalysts for removing contaminants. Using a combination of experiments (including kinetics, electrochemical analysis, spectroscopy, and chromatography), quantum chemical calculations, and machine learning models, we've gained insights into the reaction kinetics, products, and mechanisms of various MnOx and representative contaminants.

Our major findings include: i) MnOx reactivity for contaminant removal depends on surface Mn(III) content, crystallinity, surface area, reduction potential, conductivity, and surface oxygen. These insights guide designing effective MnOx for cost-effective water treatment. ii) AI/machine learning can predict contaminant reactivity in advanced oxidation processes. iii) There's a correlation between Mn partial atomic charge and oxidation state, simplifying Mn oxidation state determination in different environments. iv) MnOx plays a vital role in forming and evolving organic matter in the environment. This research improves our understanding of how MnOx can be utilized to create new treatment technologies that are effective and environmentally friendly.

Broader Impacts

Understanding the crucial role of MnOx in contaminant removal is essential for four reasons: 1) It allows us to design materials that can outperform existing MnOx, not only in removing contaminants but also in applications like catalytic water oxidation for hydrogen production; 2) The developed models connect MnOx reactivity in contaminant removal to fields such as alternative energy production and clean chemical synthesis; 3) Removing emerging contaminants from drinking water safeguards human health, while cleaning wastewater protects receiving waters, enabling more water reuse. Cleaned groundwater and soil/sediments protect the environment from long-term contamination, ensuring a continuous supply of safe water. 4) Understanding the formation of organic matter under environmental conditions helps regulate carbon cycling and enhances soil fertility for sustainable agriculture. In addition, this research showcases how innovative AI/machine learning tools can be used to tackle environmental issues effectively.

This project has supported the training of four Ph.D. students (including one female) and five undergraduate students (including two females). We've shared our discoveries at numerous professional meetings, institutions, and in peer-reviewed publications. Additionally, we've planned various outreach activities, such as workshops for students from preK to 12th grade, an online calculator for the public to access our machine learning models easily (even without much coding experience), local workshops for emerging contaminants and climate action planning, career counseling for undergraduates and graduate students, and ideas for four college senior design projects. These initiatives aim to raise awareness and spark interest in engineering advancements, contributing to a broader understanding of these innovations.

 


Last Modified: 12/20/2023
Modified by: Huichun Zhang
